perturbation.original_text:
Customer or IBM may terminate this Agreement for material breach of this Agreement by the other upon written notice containing the
specific nature and dates of the material breach.  The breaching party will have thirty (30) days from receipt of notice to cure such
breach, except for nonpayment by Customer, which must be cured within five (5) days from receipt of notice. If such breach has not
been timely cured, then the non-breaching party may immediately terminate this Agreement upon written notice.
perturbation.changed_text:
Customer or IBM may terminate this Agreement for material breach of this Agreement by the other upon written notice containing the
specific nature and dates of the material breach. The breaching party will have ten (10) days from receipt of notice to cure such
breach, except for nonpayment by Customer, which must be cured within two (2) days from receipt of notice. If such breach has not
been timely cured, then the non-breaching party may immediately terminate this Agreement upon written notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a 30-day cure period for material breaches and a 5-day cure period for non-payment. This modification reduces these cure periods to 10 days and 2 days, respectively. This may conflict with state laws that require longer cure periods for certain breaches, especially those involving significant investments or essential services. In many jurisdictions, a shorter cure period could be deemed unreasonable, rendering the termination clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with state laws regarding reasonable cure periods for contract breaches, such as those found in commercial codes or specific industry regulations.

perturbation.original_text:
IBM invoices will specify the amount due. Payment is due and payable by month end for any invoice received by the 10th of the month,
otherwise payment is due thirty (30) days from receipt of invoice. Customer agrees to pay accordingly, including any late payment fees.
perturbation.changed_text: IBM invoices will specify the amount due. Payment is due and payable within 10 days from receipt of invoice. Customer agrees to pay accordingly, including any late payment fees.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allowed payment by month end for invoices received by the 10th, or 30 days from receipt. The modified text mandates payment within 10 days of receipt of invoice, irrespective of when the invoice is received. This could contradict state prompt payment laws, which often specify minimum payment terms, especially for contracts involving small businesses or specific industries. A 10-day payment window may be deemed unreasonably short, especially considering mailing times and internal approval processes, thereby creating non-compliance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with state prompt payment laws, which may specify minimum payment terms for certain contracts.

perturbation.original_text:
Actions Period
Neither party will bring a legal action related to this Agreement more than two years after the cause of action accrued.
perturbation.changed_text:
Actions Period
Neither party will bring a legal action related to this Agreement more than six months after the cause of action accrued.
perturbation.explanation: This section sets a contractual limitation period for legal actions. The original text allows two years, while the modified version reduces this to six months. This change directly contradicts the standard statutes of limitations for contract disputes, which are typically longer than six months (often several years, depending on the state and the nature of the contract). A six-month limitation period may be deemed unreasonably short and unenforceable, especially if it prejudices a party's ability to adequately investigate and prepare a legal claim.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with state statutes of limitations for contract disputes, which are typically longer than six months.
